main-text.text: State Capitol P.O. Box 2062 Albany, NY 12220-0062 www.its.ny.gov
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 1.0 Purpose and Benefits
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: The purpose of this policy is to provide a method for obtaining an exception to compliance with a published security policy or standard issued by New York State (NYS) Office of Information Technology Services (ITS).
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 2.0 Authority
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Section 103(10) of the State Technology Law provides ITS with the authority to establish statewide technology policies, including technology and security standards. Section 2 of Executive Order No. 117 1 , established January 2002, provides the State Chief Information Officer with the authority to oversee, direct and coordinate the establishment of information technology policies, protocols, and standards for State government, including hardware, software, security, and business re-engineering. Details regarding this authority can be found in NYS ITS Policy, NYS-P08-002 Authority to Establish State Enterprise Information Technology (IT) Policy, Standards and Guidelines .
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 3.0 Scope
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: This policy applies to all "State Entities" (SE), defined as "State Government" entities as defined in Executive Order 117, established January 2002, or "State Agencies" as defined in Section 101 of the State Technology Law. This includes
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: $^{1}$ All references to Executive Order 117 refer to that which was originally issued by Governor George E. Pataki on January 28, 2002 and continued by Executive Order 5 issued by Governor Eliot Spitzer on January 1, 2007, Executive Order 9 issued by Governor David A. Patterson on June 18, 2008, Executive Order 2 issued by Governor Andrew M. Cuomo on January 1, 2011 and Executive Order 6 issued by Governor Kathy Hochul on October 8, 2021
main-text.name: Footnote

main-text.text: employees and all third parties (such as local governments, consultants, vendors, and contractors) that use or access any IT resource for which the SE has administrative responsibility, including systems managed or hosted by third parties on behalf of the SE. While an SE may adopt a different policy, it must include the requirements set forth in this one.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 4.0 Information Statement
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: An exception may be granted by the Chief Information Security Officer (CISO) of ITS, or their designee, for non-compliance with a policy or standard. Justification for approval of policy or standard exceptions include, but are not limited to:
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: · Implementation of a solution with equivalent protection to the requirements in the CISO policy or standard.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: · Implementation of a solution with superior protection to the requirements in the CISO policy or standard.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: · Impending retirement of a system.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: · Inability to implement the policy or standard due to some limitation (e.g., technical constraint, business limitation or statutory requirement).
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: Exceptions are reviewed on a case-by-case basis and their approval is not automatic. Exceptions that are granted will be for a specific period of time. Upon expiration of the exception, an extension of the exception may be requested, if it is still required.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: The exception request must be submitted on a completed Exception Request Form and must include:
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: · Description of the non-compliance
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: · Anticipated length of non-compliance
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: · Proposed assessment of risk associated with non-compliance
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: · Proposed compensating controls for managing the risk associated with non- compliance
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: · Proposed corrective action plan or mitigation plan
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: · Proposed review date to evaluate progress toward compliance
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: · The Exception Request Form must be signed by the following:
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: o Information/Business Owner
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: o Information Security Officer (ISO)/Designated Security Representative
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: Page 2 of 4
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: o Chief Information Officer (CIO): (Agency/Portfolio CIO)
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: Commissioner/Executive Deputy Commissioner (or equivalent) If the non-compliance with the security policy or standard is due to a superior solution, an exception is still required. Such instances will be evaluated for possible inclusion into published policy or standard.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Upon submission of the Exception Request Form, the CISO's office will contact the requester to confirm receipt and request additional information, if needed. Once all required information has been received, the CISO will either grant or deny the request.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Upon approval, the CISO's office will send the approved Exception Request Form to the requestor. If the request is denied, the Exception Request Form will be returned with a brief explanation of why the CISO denied the request.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: In the event that the request is denied, the Commissioner/Executive Deputy Commissioner and the CIO who signed the Exception Request Form may request a meeting with the State CIO and the CISO to discuss the circumstances giving rise to the request and means of addressing those circumstances.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 5.0 Compliance
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: This policy shall take effect upon publication. Compliance is required with all enterprise policies and standards. ITS may amend its policies and standards at any time; compliance with amended policies and standards is required.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 6.0 Definitions of Key Terms
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Except for terms defined in this policy, all terms shall have the meanings found in http://www.its.ny.gov/glossary.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 7.0 Contact Information
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Submit all inquiries and requests for future enhancements to the policy owner at:
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Chief Information Security Office Reference: NYS-P13-001 NYS Office of Information Technology Services 1220 Washington Avenue, Building 5 Albany, NY 12226
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Email: CISO@its.ny.gov
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Statewide technology policies, standards, and guidelines may be found at the following website: http://www.its.ny.gov/tables/technologypolicyindex
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Page 3 of 4
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: 8.0 Revision History
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: This policy should be reviewed consistent with the requirements set forth in NYS-P08002 Authority to Establish State Enterprise Information Technology (IT) Policy, Standards and Guidelines .
main-text.name: Text
